channel.title: Finding the right JDK for YOUR compiler/path/classpath
channel.description:
I've noticed WAY too many people having problems finding their JDK so they can compile whatever source they need to compile. My first recommendation is getting an [url=http://www.eclipse.org/downloads/packages/eclipse-ide-java-ee-developers/junor]IDE[/url]; you do NOT have to compile with an IDE, when you run the program it will compile. You can find more information about Eclispe with [url=http://google.com]Google[/url].
If that just doesn't fly, then you need to edit your compiler/path/classpath and replace that crappy jdk version that doesn't work with the one that [i]does[/i] work.
For Windows XP 32 (x86) Bit users: • go to Start (bottom left)>My Computer>Local Disk (C:/)>Program Files (x86)>Java
For Windows XP 64 Bit users: • go to Start (bottom left)>My Computer>Local Disk (C:/)>Program Files>Java
For Windows Vista/7 users: • go to start (bottom right)>search "Java">go to the folder "Java">find the jdk folder
[IMG]http://i578.photobucket.com/albums/ss224/Tigerkrager/JDKsetup.png[/img]
Now look at this picture, the "circled" folder is what you will replace in your .bat program. So if you have "jdk1.6.0_05" set as your classpath/path/in your compiler replace it with EXACTLY the one that is shown in your folder. (For example, only I would replace jdk1.6.0_05 with jdk1.7.0_05, because jdk1.7.0_05 is the version I have, not you.)
So, what did that do? Well, you found out your jdk version (whatever the folder was called) and now go back to your compiler/path/classpath and change it accordingly.
Any questions post here, I will [b]not[/b] answer non-related jdk issues, and I will not do it for you.

@the_elve_age wrote:

I’ve noticed WAY too many people having problems finding their JDK so they can compile whatever source they need to compile. My first recommendation is getting an IDE; you do NOT have to compile with an IDE, when you run the program it will compile. You can find more information about Eclispe with Google.

• go to Start (bottom left)>My Computer>Local Disk (C:/)>Program Files (x86)>Java

For Windows XP 64 Bit users:

Now look at this picture, the “circled” folder is what you will replace in your .bat program.
